div.head: Title
Genre
div.p: Narrative poem, rendering in verse scenes from The Monastery by Walter Scott.

div.head: Manuscripts
div.p: MS IA; MS III.

div.head: Date
div.p: A range of 1827–29 is possible. “Book I” and “Book II” may have been composed as early as 1827–28; “Book III” and “Book IV” may have been completed by March 1829.

W. G. Collingwood dated the work from the “early part of 1828” or “first half of 1828”. based on his analysis of the sequence in which Ruskin entered poetry selections in MS III (see Composition and Publication; and see Poems [4o, 1891], 1:262, 272; Poems [8o, 1891] 1:263, 273; Ruskin, Works, 2:530). E. T. Cook and Alexander Wedderburn disagreed and ascribed the work to 1827, in the belief that the poem was “a result of [Ruskinʼs] visit to Scotland in that year” (Ruskin, Works 2:260 n. 1; and see 276 n. 1). Helen Viljoen was initially inclined to accept the earlier date, because she considered the hand in the IA draft to be “very childish”, but then she decided that Cook and Wedderburn had “no legitimate basis” for correcting Collingwoodʼs date of 1828 (“Helen Gill Viljoen Papers”, box F, transcription of “The Monastery”).

The reasoning by the editors of the Library Edition does seem to stand on the most speculative evidence, dependent solely on Ruskinʼs comment in Praeterita that he “used to read the Abbot at Kinross, and the Monastery in Glen Farg” (Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1; 35:16). While Ruskin may well have associated Walter Scottʼs novels with landmarks along the Ruskinsʼ routes to Scotland in the 1820s, why should these associations be tied so specifically to the journey of 1827? It is not known when Ruskin first read Scottʼs Monastery or heard it read to him. That journey did result, however, in the writing that immediately precedes Ruskinʼs “The Monastery” in MS III—the anthology, “poetry discriptive” (see also Tours of 1826–27). Whether “The Monastery”—or at least its first Book—should be considered a contemporaneous part of that 1827 poetry project, or, as Collingwood contends, an insertion in that place from a later time, the poemʼs juxtaposition with an anthology of poems describing Lochleven and Glenfarg, among other places, does appear to confirm the associations that Ruskin commemorated in Praeterita.

As explained in Composition and Publication, the only documented record of Ruskinʼs labor on “The Monastery” dates from March 1829, and even that passing reference in a letter is ambiguous. The statement might mean that he was returning to composition and/or fair copy of the poem itself, or simply that he was working on something in MS III, which he identified by its contents—that is, the Red Book that contains his versification, “The Monastery”. Based on the concatenation of evidence in Composition and Publication, it appears likely that, in March 1829, he did compose and/or fair‐copy Books III–IV or a portion of them (which he left incomplete), while Books I–II of the poem dated from 1827 or (more likely) 1828.

div.head: Composition and Publication
div.p: In a 4 March 1829 letter to her husband, Margaret Ruskin referred to Johnʼs writing “a novel” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 185)—presumably referring to this versification of scenes from the first four chapters of Walter Scottʼs novel, Monastery (1820). In a 10 March letter to his father, John confirmed: “I am trying to get that red book of mine which has the Monastery in it finished, by the time you come home” (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 192). Of the surviving Red Books, only MS III contains any portion of this work; and while Ruskinʼs statement is ambiguous, as remarked in Date, respecting whether he was working on the poem or simply in the Red Book containing the poem, Margaret indicated to John James that she saw definite progress on the poem itself: “he has commenced writing a novel & a Sermon both as far as they have gone very tolerable I assure you” (letter of 4 March 1829 [Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 185]). The “Sermon” corresponds well in date with “A Theme” and Sermon Notes [“christs intercession”], fragments that are embedded in the midst of draft of “On Skiddaw and Derwent Water” (i.e., the MS II draft witness, “description of skiddaw & lake derwent”).

In MS III, “The Monastery” immediately follows a group of poems entitled “poetry discriptive”, which Ruskin fair‐copied no earlier than May 1827, and probably sometime between September 1827 and New Yearʼs 1828 (see “Wales”: Date; and “poetry discriptive”: Date). There is no physical break between the anthology and the “novel” to indicate a change in genre or project, so it is possible that Ruskin considered “The Monastery” to be a continuation of the “poetry discriptive”. Thus, with travel poems about Glenfarg and Loch Leven adjoined to the versification of the novel, this passage bears witness to Ruskinʼs autobiographical recollection that he “used to read the Abbot at Kinross, and the Monastery in Glen Farg, which I confused with ‘Glendearg’ [the fictional setting of the novel; see Discussion, and see also Glenfarg (place)], and thought that the White Lady had as certainly lived by the streamlet [the Farg] in that glen of the Ochils, as the Queen of Scots in the island of Loch Leven” (Ruskin, Works, 35:16).

When the editors of the Library Edition associated this sentence in Praeterita with “The Monastery” as proof that Ruskinʼs verse novel must be be associated with the family journey to Perth, Scotland, in 1827 (see Date; and see also Tours of 1826–27), they evidently did not draw this conclusion from the juxtaposition of “The Monastery” with “poetry discriptive”, since they believed the latter to date from 1826 (Ruskin, Works, 2:260 n. 1, and see 535). Although the editors were mistaken in dating the anthology, its corrected dating supports their premise that the 1827 Scotland tour forms a terminus a quo for “The Monastery”. But how much time separated the verse novel from the tour poem anthology? For this question, the only evidence is handwriting.

The hand for the verse novel uses print lettering similar to that for “poetry discriptive”, but smaller. Size of lettering in fact varies considerably within the anthology, as well, the smallest being used for its first poem, “Ragland Castle”; still, regardless of size, and despite the similarity in formation of letters, there is greater affinity between the lettering throughout the poems in “poetry discriptive” and that used for the original versions of two of its poems, “Wales” and “Spring: Blank Verse”, as fair‐copied in a May 1827 letter by Ruskin to his father. By comparison, the lettering for “The Monastery” is distinctive for its studied attention to punctuation, which is largly neglected in the 1827 fair copies of “Wales”, “Spring: Blank Verse”, and the poems in “poetry discriptive”. Almost every line of “The Monastery” ends with a prominent comma, formed to look like book print, with a dot and a curl, although the commas hover above the baseline like a swimming tadpole. There are also semicolons, which are consistently formed upside down, with the comma above the point. Similarly carefully formed but eccentric punctuation can be found in “Eudosia” in MS IV. The typeface‐like commas are continued, though they now fall on the baseline; there are no upside‐down semicolons, but a new oddity turns up in the form of a two‐point ellipsis, like a colon on its side, its function unclear. What most tellingly links the punctuation practice in “Eudosia” with that in “The Monastery” is not just its careful drawing combined with eccentric formation and meaning, but the fact that its prominent use abruptly gives out altogether after several pages of fair‐copying, suggesting that Ruskin added the marks all at once, layering over top of the already fair‐copied text. Evidently, he had not yet learned to integrate punctuation as a rhetorical and grammatical element of writing, but treated it as effectively a decorative feature to enhance the imitation of typeface.

“Eudosia” supplies a benchmark date of 28 September 1828, which Ruskin incorportated into the half‐title and first page of Book I (the same divisions used for “The Monastery”). Accordingly, a timeline falls into place, starting with Ruskinʼs use of pen and ink, documented by his mother in April 1827 (see The Ruskin Family Handwriting). The neglect of a physical separation does not necessarily imply, moreover, that Ruskin misunderstood the difference between the brief lyric mode of descriptive verse and a long narrative poem: from the outset of the fair copy, he divided “The Monastery” into numbered “books” that corresponded to chapters in Scottʼs novel—a sequence that Ruskin could have extended to the end of the original story, but that he never carried beyond Scottʼs chapter four, so far as the record shows.

Ruskinʼs 10 March 1829 letter to his father implies that John James was already familiar with some portion of the versified novel, so the first book or books may have significantly predated his “finishing” MS III. In fact, Ruskinʼs promise “to get that red book of mine which has the Monastery in it finished” does not necessarily include a commitment to work on “The Monastery” itself, which is certainly not complete in any obvious sense. However, the physical disposition of the fair copy in MS III can be interpreted as reflecting two distinct stages of labor on the poem, with a break in time possibly occurring between books 1–2 and 3–4.

In MS III, books 1–2 run from the last poem fair‐copied in “poetry discriptive” to almost the end of the notebook (pp. 70–80), concluding with a colophon, “END OF BOOK SECOND / HERNE HILL / DULWICH”; and then, with the direction “go back to page 52” inserted as part of the colophon, the poem resumes on page 52 with book 3, and extending through book 4, which seems uncompleted. The pages occupied by the latter two books (pp. 52–58, plus three blank pages, 59–61) take up the available leaves that fall between those containing a group of poems dated 9 March 1829 (pp. 36–50, plus the blank p. 51) and the leaves containing the “poetry discriptive” (pp. 62–70). In Ruskinʼs process of filling these interstitial leaves with books 3–4, the space occupied by “poetry discriptive” unquestionably presented a terminus ad quem of available space, while a terminus a quo was likely already present in the form of the March 9 poetry group. While the latter inference cannot be proven, since Ruskin could have decided arbitrarily to resume with book 3 on p. 52, with nothing in particular framing that space, the physical evidence does suggest that he composed and/or fair‐copied at least books 3 and 4 of “The Monastery” at about the same time that he was filling a preceding set of pages with a group of poems that he prominently and repeatedly dated 9 March 1829. This frenzy of activity was meant to demonstrate, as he announced to his father on 10 March, that he would “get that red book of mine [MS III] which has the Monastery in it finished, by the time you come home”. (For the March 9 group, see its last‐copied poem, “Of rocks first and of caverns now i sing”).

MS IA includes a one‐sheet, ink, longhand set of lines that forms part of the MS III poemʼs “book third”, as well as a one‐sheet pencil version of part of the MS III poemʼs “book second” (see part 2, MS IA, “Content”, a). It is possible that the MS IA pencil version of part of “book second” is earlier than 1829, since the fair copy of “book third” is the portion positioned following the March 9 group in the MS III, while “book second” runs continuously to the end of MS III. Even the MS IA ink version of part of “book third”, conceivably, could significantly predate its March 1829 fair‐copying.

The MS IA copies, then, do hold open the possibility of a starting date perhaps up to a year prior to the projectʼs termination in 1829. Moreover, given Ruskinʼs hectic pace of writing and fair‐copying for New Yearʼs 1828 and for his fatherʼs 1829 birthday (see “Harry and Lucy”, Vol. III, “A Battle: Irregular Measure”, “Battle of Waterloo: A Play in Two Acts”), it seems barely credible that even Ruskin could have produced all of his “novel” during the same period. If these indications are sound, I believe the onset of composition is unlikely to have been much earlier than the middle of 1828, however, since the handwriting and punctuation in the first two books is reminiscent of “Eudosia”.

Since the extant manuscript evidence places books 3–4 of the poem (or, at least, their fair‐copying) squarely in 1829, while only permitting an earlier date for books 1–2, the case for assigning an earlier date to some portion of the poem must depend on internal evidence—the events captured from Scottʼs novel, and the order in which Ruskin set them to verse. See Discussion: since book 1 lifts events out of their order in Scott, the poem could represent an earlier, isolated versification, which Ruskin only later in 1829 decided to develop—“commenc[ing] writing a novel”, as his mother said.
(so far, that is, as “The Monastery” ever did reach completion).

div.head: Historical Context of Scottʼs Novel and the Arrangement of Ruskinʼs Selections
div.p: The political context was set in motion prior to the time of novelʼs opening by what Scott elsewhere dubbed the “rough wooing” of 1544–45, whereby Henry VIII sought to force a union between his son and heir, Edward (1537–53), and the infant Mary, queen of Scots (1542–87), daughter of James V of Scotland (1512–42) and Mary of Guise (1515–60). Henry hoped to break Scotlandʼs traditional alliance with France and annex the country to an assured Tudor succession. In Scotland, treaties to this effect were guided by James Hamilton, earl of Arran (1519–75), who had been appointed governor of Scotland and tutor to Mary, upon the death of James V. Arranʼs Protestantism made him sympathetic to the union; however, a reaction of anti‐English feeling, along with the aggression of Henryʼs increasing demands, caused the arrangement to founder. The Scottish parliament condemned the treaties, and adherents of the Auld Alliance with France regained the upper hand over the Protestant faction. Incensed, Henry appointed troops under Edward Seymour, earl of Hertford (1500–52), to “put all to fyre and swoord”. In two compaigns, Hertford destroyed portions of Edinburgh, and he harried castles and monasteries around the Firth of Forth, including Melrose Abbey on which the fictional Monastery of Saint Mary is loosely modeled (Mitchinson 103-4, 105-6; Fielding “Historical Note” 434–35).

After Henryʼs death, Hertford, now duke of Somerset and lord protector under Edward VI, renewed efforts to subdue Scotland by marching north in 1547 and winning a decisive victory at the Battle of Pinkie, near Edinburgh. This battle is the historical reference point at the start of Scottʼs Monastery, the conflict that made widows of both Lady Avenel and her lesser ranked counterpart, Elspet Glendinning. As dramatized by the novelʼs opening encounter between an occupying English soldier and Elspet and her two sons, who can barely contain their defiance of the “heretic” Englishman, the military victory not only failed to quell Scottish resistance, but undermined the Scottish Protestant faction. Mary of Guise continued successfully to arrange for her daughterʼs betrothal to the French dauphin, later François II (1544–60). Hatred of the English invaders and the reaffirmation of the Auld Alliance put Scottish Protestants on the offensive, who had once looked to England for support—a hope that soon turned untenable with the accession of “Bloody” Queen Mary to the English throne (ruled 1553–58)—and helped drive Scottish Protestantism toward more radical Calvinism (Mitchinson 107–8).

In book 1 of his versification of the novel, Ruskin lifts events out of their sequential narrative order, and begins with an episode involving the White Lady. Thus, his version de‐emphasizes the novelʼs staging of political conflict and religious controversies of the Scottish Reformation, and instead favors the storyʼs supernatural elements—precisely reversing the critical reception of the novel, which was almost unanimous in condemning the White Lady as a childish invention. Ruskinʼs choice and arrangement of episodes seems designed to concentrate the episodes from the opening of the novel that contain apparitions. Moreover, with one exception, Ruskin withholds the names of the fathers from the monastery—referring to them only (and sometimes confusedly) as “the monk”, “the abbot”, and so on—as if to avoid personalizing the Roman Catholic clerics. Ruskinʼs episodes correspond to Scottʼs chapters as follows:
Book 1. The Monastery, from chapters 5, 7.
Invocation to White Lady (original to Ruskin?). A monk (Father Philip, the sacristan of the Monastery of Saint Mary) is denied passage over the Tweed by the warder of the drawbridge. Preparing to ford the river on his mule, he encounters the White Lady and offers to carry her across the stream, only to be thrown from his mount by the lady. While the monk grasps “a black volume”—Lady Avenelʼs vernacular bible, which he has confiscated—Ruskin omits the explanation earlier in Scottʼs chapter of the monksʼ zeal to crush heretical Reform ideas spreading in the region, and Philipʼs discovery of the forbidden book on a pastoral visit to the Tower of Glendearg, where Lady Avenel and her daughter are residing. Skipping to Scottʼs chapter seven, Ruskin follows Philip home to the monastery, where, still amazed and gibbering snatches of the White Ladyʼs song. Ruskin curtails Philipʼs interview with Abbot and Father Eustace, cutting to the latterʼs resolve to visit Glendearg themselves.
Ruskinʼs book 2 begins with the opening of Scottʼs chap. 3, the widowing of the Lady of Avenel and her removal with her daughter to the shepherdʼs cottage of Martin and Tibb Tacket; and book 2 then moves to Scottʼs chap. 2, the confrontation between Captain Stawarth Bolton and Dame Glendinning and her two sons of Glendearg.
Ruskinʼs book 3 versifies the remainder of Scottʼs chap. 3—Martin, Tibb, Mary, and the Lady of Avenelʼs journey to Dame Glendinningʼs residence in Glendearg (which Ruskin calls “Glenfarg” and “Glendarg” [see Ruskin, Works, 35:16]), and their attempted passage across a bog, when Mary and the pony Shagram see the White Lady signaling them to safety.
Ruskinʼs book 4 is from Scottʼs chap. 4, the apparition of her dead father to Mary Avenel on Halloween night.
Scott—therefore, possibly representing an earlier, isolated versification of Scottʼs chapter 5, which Ruskin decided only later in 1829 to develop—points to a fascination with Scottʼs fifth chapter that was deeply entrenched in Ruskinʼs childhood. Bridges had interested him since 1823, when his aunt presented him with the cherished model of Waterloo Bridge (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 127). The White Lady may have been associated in Ruskinʼs mind with Byronʼs “witch of the waters at the Alps” in no. 3, “Harry and Lucy”, Vol. 1 (1826–27), who occurs to Harry when he “observed a rainbow and a rising mist under it which his fancy soon transformed into a female form” (in book 3 of “The Monastery”, the White Lady is a “form appearing like a fog”). Of course, these associations could just as likely have traveled the other way, with witches and bridges leading to his later fascination with the perils of the White Lady in “The Monastery”.

If book 1 probes images that were profoundly arresting for Ruskin throughout his earlier years, books 2–4 are enriched by a possible connection with the death of Ruskinʼs Aunt Jessie of Perth and the Ruskinsʼ subsequent adoption of her daughter Mary (see nos. 25–26 Travel Itinerary and Tour Notes [1828], “The Sound of the Sea”). Cousin Mary came to Herne Hill in July 1828 (A Tour to the Lakes in Cumberland, 7), an event that might well have put Ruskin in mind of the two families joining in “The Monastery”—the widowed Lady Avenel and her daughter Mary with the widowed Dame Glendinning and her two sons. In this light, the end of Ruskinʼs poem is moving, breaking off abruptly with the childrenʼs sighting of the “man in the spence”, the ghost of Maryʼs father, and the youngest boyʼs tears—events that Ruskin slightly, and perhaps significantly, alters from the novel.

One other association may be noted, which returns the dating to early 1829, when Ruskin certainly fair‐copied books 3–4, and probably composed at least some portion of them. It is striking that Margaret expressed admiration of her son equally for writing a “novel” and for making sermon notes (Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 185). Margaret did not necessarily consider these incompatible pursuits, as did some evangelicals, but she might have encouraged Ruskinʼs reading of The Monastery, owing to her opposition to Cathotic Emancipation, being debated at the time (see Burd, ed., Ruskin Family Letters, 177). Scottʼs novel makes heroes of the Reformers and satirizes monastic failings, although Ruskinʼs poem largely neglects these themes.

div.head: Textual Note
div.p: The copytext is taken from MS III. One peculiarity of punctuation, especially in the first two books, is the frequent use of a colon, which seems to indicate a pause, as does the two‐point ellipsis in “Eudosia” . (In fact, that strange mark in “Eudosia” may be a colon turned on its side.) Perpetually inventive, in “The Monastery”, Ruskin has come up with yet another mark of his own, the upside‐down semicolon, or comma above a period. I cannot distinguish a consistent function for this mark much different from that of Ruskinʼs colon, so, where it appears, I have put a colon in square brackets.
With book 3, the punctuation becomes less idiosyncratic. The MS IA draft is entirely unpunctuated.
